abstract.text: Ability to control the implicit or explicit animation
of control state updates on layers or views respectively.
ControlStateUpdatable and ControlStateDelegate conform to this.
Protocol to support updating controls
their backgrounds
(“combined”), based on current state.
NOTE: This specialized protocol exists solely to be used with
the default implementation – which applies the theme directly
to the conforming item
it’s background. If implementing
“updateForStateChange()” yourself (or if the conforming item
is a guide) use the “ControlStateUpdatable” protocol instead.
(In fact, any override to “updateForStateChange()” will not even be hit.)
The conforming item must be a UIControl, CustomControl or
ControlStateDependent and the background (associated type)
must be a CustomControl or ControlStateDependent in order
to use this protocol.
This protocol includes implicit animation support.
Override duration/timing/animation type as needed.
Animation type determines the type of supported animation,
being “for views” which provides an explicit property animator
(and implicit animation of sub-layers via CA transaction)
or “for layers” which provides the built-in implicit animations
(with adjustable duration/curve via this protocol).
Default is nil, which takes the type of the object getting
the control state updates. Note: in most cases it’s not
necessary to set this (i.e. just leave it to return nil by default)
because even in special cases where the control is a view
but the thing updated is a layer, wrapping the layer changes in a
view property animator (which is what will happen under the hood)
effectively provides the same animation as an implicit layer animation.
If you absolutely need implicit layer animations then return .layer.
To handle animations independently but still take advantage of theme-
based property changes being fired via control state updates
(presumably within the scope of animation blocks) return “.override”.
For example, in case “.override” is used you can then call
mutate.animate(..) { $0.highlighted(true) } which uses your
animator but still allows the highlight to update the visual
appearance according to the control state update.
This will also allow implicit layer animations to proceed as normal.
To stop all animations return 0.0 from “controlStateAnimationDuration”.
Protocol to support updating the appearance of controls
based on their current state.
In case of creating theme styles with control states
(e.g. *“login” + .disabled ) use this protocol to apply
the theme in “updateForStateChange()” which will be called
whenever the control state changes. Always pass the
received control state to the apply() method.
NOTE: it’s not always necessary to implement the method
of this protocol as there is already a default implementation
which applies the theme directly to the item.
In order to use the default implementation, the conforming
item must be a UIControl, CustomControl (view or layer) or
ControlStateDependent (view or layer). (For CustomControl
and ControlStateDependent, guides are supported only by
implementing “updateForStateChange()”.)
See also the “Background” and “Combined” specializations of
this protocol for alternative use-cases.
This protocol includes implicit animation support.
Override duration/timing/animation type as needed.
Protocol to support updating the appearance of items
based on their current state – which includes more
than the stock values found in UIControl.State.
This protocol supports types that are not themselves
UIControls but have their own control state,
including views, layers and guides. This protocol is
considered “adhoc” because it also includes conformance
to ControlStateUpdatable which (via it’s default
implementation) ensures that control state updates are
passed down in order to make visual changes.
Assuming the default implementation of ControlStateUpdatable
is used and the item does not already conform to
ThemeAccessible, you will need to conform to ThemeAccessible
separately so that the updates can use the appropriate theme.
CancelButton2 supports canceling and dismissing a related
ancestor Presentable if initialized with “dismissive”.
Adhoc actions can be attached to this button or via
delegate using Mutator event API.
This button is automatically “control state updatable” for
theme changes on the button itself and potentially on a
background Shape if it exists.
(This also presumes the button or super type (e.g. UIView)
conforms to ThemeAccessible or ThemeOverridable.)
This button is also Dismissable if “dismissive” is passed.
This button supports constructing with data on attachment
(i.e. via in(..data:) method). The data type to provide
is a tuple of button text, optional button outset,
and optional corner spec. Using this approach will cause a
rectangular shape background (that is also control state
updatable) to be added. (The rectangle will obtain corner
spec if provided.) Passing a theme to in() is optional
but preferred (the theme will be applied to the button
as well as the shape).
(You may create multiple buttons this way by providing
multiple data tuples as per normal with ConstructibleWithData.)
If you prefer to use your own custom shape for this button
then do not use the construct-with-data approach or alternatively,
override the construct(data:) method. But keep in mind that
your custom shape should pass “updatable:true” to ensure
it can participate in control state updates.
If you pass a theme that inherits from the built-in theme
(via Theme.getBuiltInTheme()) then this button and it’s
background will inherit the default styling.
(If you want the background to receive the default styling
your Theme must also statically conform to ExtendedStyleAccessible
with the static property ExtendedStyleDefaults, with
usesButtonBackgroundLayers set to true.)
If you choose to use this initializer but do not want the
background to appear at all you may either hide it manually:
e.g. .with { $0.shapes }.hide()
or create a style in your theme to hide it:
e.g. MyCancelButton.self > Shape.self => .contentAlpha(0.0)
CAVEAT: If you want to use a custom Model type (not the one
that is already on ControlButton2) you cannot use this class due to
generics limitations. Use DismissableButton or Button instead with
ControlStateCombinedUpdatable as necessary. You will also
probably want to conform to DismissableButtonConfigurable
to get the tap action to dismiss.
See also CancelButton that supports regular layer backgrounds.
Switchable buttons support toggling the selected state
of the button. Check selected state via “isSelected”.
(Similar to UISwitch or a “check box” in web programming.)
SwitchableControlButton2 is automatically “control state
updatable” for theme changes on the button itself and
potentially on a background Shape if it exists.
(This also presumes the button or super type (e.g. UIView)
conforms to ThemeAccessible or ThemeOverridable.)
Protocol to support updating the appearance of controls
based on their current state. All methods are optional.
Fires a different callback for each type of state change.
Optionally control the duration/timing/supression
of implicit/explicit animations of the updates.
Alternatively, use “ControlStateUpdatable” which provides
theme support via a single callback.
Exclusive buttons support exclusive selection state
within a group of sibling Exclusive buttons.
(Similar to a “radio group” in web programming,
and functionally similar to UISegmentedControl.)
ExclusiveControlButton is automatically “control state
updatable” for theme changes on the button itself and
potentially on a ControlBackground (layer) if it exists.
(This also presumes the button or super type (e.g. UIView)
conforms to ThemeAccessible or ThemeOverridable.)

Protocol to support updating the
of controls
based on their current state.
NOTE: This specialized protocol exists solely to be used with
the default implementation – which applies the theme directly
to the background. If implementing “updateForStateChange()”
yourself (or if the conforming item is a guide) use the
“ControlStateUpdatable” protocol instead. (In fact, any override
to “updateForStateChange()” will not even be hit.)
The conforming item can be anything, but the associated type

ControlStateDependent or CustomControl in order to use this protocol.
This protocol includes implicit animation support.
Override duration/timing/animation type as needed.
Animation timing curve for control state update animations.
Default is .easeOut, which allows a quick initial animation
(e.g. initial tap down) and more gradual completion.
Timing curve types include .curve(), .spring() and .cubic().
Layer animations are compatible with .curve() and .cubic() types.

Ability to control the implicit or explicit animation
of control state updates on layers or views respectively.
ControlStateUpdatable and ControlStateDelegate conform to this.
Duration of the control state update animations.
Default is 0.3 sec. On layers, implicit animation of animatable
layer properties and on views explicit animation of view properties.
Set this to 0.0 to disable animations.
TIP: If object is ControlStateAccessible (UIControl, CustomControl
or ControlStateDependent) use “controlState” to help determine duration.
Example: “return controlState.contains(.focused) ? 1.0 : 0.3”
